title: Coronation Street spoilers: Boss reveals why Sinead has to die
text:
Coronation Street boss Iain MacLeod has revealed why he chose to kill the character of Sinead Tinker (Katie McGlynn) as part of the cervical cancer storyline, explaining that he didn’t want to paint life as a fairy tale and felt it would be doing an injustice if Sinead was seen to just move on and forget about her serious illness.

The storyline of Sinead’s diagnosis and ordeal has been a long running one – and was inherited by Iain by former Corrie boss Kate Oates, leaving him at a crossroads over whether he would kill off the character or have her survive.

At the time he took over, he told Metro.co.uk that a decision was yet to be made – and he added that Katie’s performances were tempting him to keep her around – but it turns out that the direction of the storyline was cemented not long after that.

Asked if it has always been his intention to end the story in this way, Iain said: ‘More or less yes. When I started Katie and I spoke at length about what the right ending would be. life does sometimes take an unbelievably cruel turn, we both felt that was the most responsible way to end the story rather than, as sometimes happens in soap, people miraculously recover from a terrible illness as if it never happened. Telling the tough version was the right version to tell.’

He added that playing out the story long term meant that the ending had to be done just right – which is why Corrie will be devoting several standalone episodes to Sinead’s final day.

Iain shared: ‘After two and a half yrs of telling a story it would be remiss of us to gallop through the end. I feel like it’s something we tend to short circuit on TV – as Ken says at one point, we’re used to seeing death on TV but usually an array of bad guys being mowed down by Bruce Willis -we are immune to the realities of it and scared of looking at it. The right thing to do was to spend a lot of time in that one room and see how it transpires.’

And despite it meaning that her time in Corrie has come to an end, Katie is in complete agreement with the producer that Sinead’s tragic end is the right one for the drama to portray.

She said: ‘Life is not a fairy tale, sometimes soaps and TV tends to do the happy ending and I thought if we’re doing the story we need to do it properly to raise awareness. I hope people who’ve been through similar find it cathartic.’
